title: An Open Letter to Fearless Regarding the Sona Changes
body:
Dear Fearless,

You may recall that I was one of the first people to reply to the announcement that Sona was going to be reworked. I made one of the [first comments](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/champions-skins/hUj8b74R-sona-update-qa?comment=0020) to that discussion and it remains the most upvoted entry. I consider myself a support main, with a specialization in Sona. I applied to the PBE, but did not receive an invite. I have played two Co-Op vs. AI matches with her on live. While that may not sound like much, it's enough to get a feel for the reality of the rework.

Put bluntly, I think you failed to provide a viable product and your communication with the community has been ineffective. This isn't personal. I don't know you nearly well enough for it to be personal. So, if you perceive any of this as an attack, please remember that it is not intended as such.

______________________________________________________________________________

**A Rework Needs to Address a Champion's Place in the Game**

Sona was not in a good place before the rework. Her pick/ban rates were low and she was routinely outclassed by more modern supports. Part of this is simply the march of new technology and part of this is Riot's desire to move toward flashy, high-risk plays. Sona was also a prime target for a rework because her auras were bad for the game. They *had to go*.

While this rework made her kit less toxic, it did nothing to address her position in the meta. There is nothing on this frame that I can point to and say, "This is a good reason to pick Sona." Keep in mind that one of the chief complaints about her kit was that she felt like an "ult delivery system," so that can't be her role now. Her ult is comparable to those of Amumu and Zyra, but people pick them for reasons other than the ult. I feel that you were hyperf-focused on getting rid of the auras and forgot to define what Sona *does*.  Now, to be fair, she had this problem before they handed her to you, but developing a role for her should have been the first step in the process.

______________________________________________________________________________

**This Rework Damages Important Ratios**

In game design, there are two important ratios: Risk vs. Reward and Reward for Effort. Both of those ratios went in the wrong direction.

*Risk vs. Reward*: Sona now has to be significantly closer to the front line, but she does not gain any benefit from this increased risk, nor were any of her stats changed to reflect this increased risk. She went from being a champion who sat at mid to long range, dipping in to poke, to a champion that has to "snuggle" down in the scrum to be effective. If you look over the complaints following the live release, this is among the most common.

It's worth noting that the enemy bruisers and assassins are going to be *itching* to have a squishy target to jump on. I saw this several times in my matches. I went forward to shield someone and was killed in an eye blink. That felt incredibly punishing. 

Another component of this ratio is that I am now forced to stack up with my allies, making me (and my allies) more vulnerable to AoE comps. The reward for tagging should *at least* be equal to the increased damage I take while stacked, but I don't feel that it is. 

There were several times in my matches where I couldn't get to my allies and this felt awful. This was especially bad in the early laning phase.

Changing the risk vs. reward ratio is also very dangerous because it causes a massive change in feel. I already own risky supports. People who liked Sona now have to adapt to a much riskier position or give up on the champion. Given that she is mostly a fan pick as it is, this is really bad.

*Reward for Effort*: The harder you have to work for something, the more you expect out of it. People learn this as children. From a play balance perspective, this means that complex mechanics and kits should provide more options, rather than increased power. League does a decent job of this, except when it comes to modal champions like Elise and Jayce.

This rework represents a *massive* increase in the amount of effort required to use her abilities "properly." I say this because it feels as though she was balanced around getting most, if not all, of her allies in her "snuggle zones." When I play her, I do not feel like I am rewarded for tagging people; I feel like this is the baseline and I am being punished when I can't get to my teammates. This is especially bad because Sona is touted as an easy, "entry-level" support.

______________________________________________________________________________

**Her New Mechanics Chew Up Mental Bandwidth**

When I use her Q, I lose effectiveness unless *both* I and my ADC gain the benefit of the secondary effect. This means that I have to slide forward, use Q, autoattack, then move to tag my teammate. This is not a simple maneuver for a routine activity. The same goes for her W.

Worse, this is a terrible use of bandwidth. Every time I use my abilities I have to track not only the position of my enemies, but those of my allies. We're not talking about a generalized sense, either. I have to track their position, likely movement and how I'm going to get to them to a precise degree. This is because the tiny "snuggle zones" require me to manage my positioning in a way that no one else is tasked with. You said that you wanted it to be a non-trivial exercise to apply the buffs, but I feel that you swung too far in the opposite direction.

______________________________________________________________________________

**I Hate Her New E With Every Fiber of my Being**

A short list:

* I have to have the same tier of boots as my allies or I can't apply the buff. I'm on a support salary.
* Applying the buff requires people to move in a way that is unnatural. No one clusters like that.
* I feel like I am being forced to choose between leveling things that I enjoy (Q and W) and the thing that I need to tag people because my effectiveness is now suddenly based on my speed. I feel that this diffuses my impact on fights.
* I feel that it's insufficient to get me out of a bad situation... *ever*. There are too many dashes and whatnot compared to the long cooldown.
* I do not feel like I can use it to get my allies onto a fleeing target that they wouldn't have caught without me.

______________________________________________________________________________

**Her "Snuggle Zones" are Incompatible with Her Passive**

When I use an ability, the first thing I want to do is move so that I'm tagging the people who weren't already in the zone because otherwise I feel like I am not getting enough out of the ability. This means that I have to choose between optimizing the buff and, you know, fighting. This is a really frustrating decision gate. It adds complexity for no reason.

______________________________________________________________________________

**Her New Mechanics Suck in Running Fights**

This is an area where I feel especially forced to level E and buy speed boots, because my closure rates with my allies is not fast enough otherwise. This feels like a direct nerf to my viability in skirmishes. Heaven help me if my allies have some sort of engage or dash mechanic, because there's no chance of getting the buff on them then.

______________________________________________________________________________

**Her W is Really Clunky**

The mechanic for applying the shield is highly counterintuitive. The shield is really short, so I either have to be right on top of the target (not gonna happen in most circumstances) or I have to move to tag them. This makes is very difficult to use the shield to prevent damage, especially in skirmish and siege situations. The only time it felt effective was during pile-on teamfights. Given the method of application, I don't understand why it couldn't last longer.

You commented in[ this post](http://boards.pbe.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/champions-gameplay-feedback/smgY9223-why-even-bother-with-sonas-shield?comment=00080000000000020000) about how people perceive the shield portion of the ability. Put bluntly, I don't think that "I'm adding a weak shield to make up for a nerfed heal" is good design theory. People want their powers to have an impact on the game.

______________________________________________________________________________

**Too Much of Her Power is On Other People**

I feel like her power was balanced around her buffing her allies, so being alone is *much* worse than it was before. I did not feel like I had any impact or survivability in *any* 1v1. This was compounded by the fact that my E was never a viable escape maneuver. 

______________________________________________________________________________

**Our Feedback was not Handled Appropriately**

Going back over your posts, I feel that the vast majority can be distilled down to "Wait until you play it" or "Our internal tests say you're wrong." Given that the PBE is an invite-only environment, the first comment is completely unacceptable, especially since it appears that invites were set *prior* to the announcement of the rework. I know at least forty people who applied, most of them immediately after the announcement. Not a single one of them got in.

This is especially upsetting because we were told that Sona was going to be on the PBE for longer than other champions because you "wanted to get it right." Not only was this not true, but the only change that was made was the increase to to her "snuggle zones." It did not feel like you listened to the community at all.

Also, if internal testing is going to be an absolute trump to our suggestions, why bother to solicit feedback at all? It was highly irritating to be told over and over what amounted to "You guys just don't get it."  It was disrespectful and unprofessional. 

______________________________________________________________________________

**Say Nice Things About Detroit**

I know that I have been really negative here and that some of it might come across as an attack, but there were some positive aspects to the rework.

* Getting rid of the auras was a good thing.
* The Heal on her W felt much better than I expected.
* I like the increased visibility of my abilities. It felt like my team could "see me" more.
* I was wrong about the increase in cooldowns. I feel like my abilities are up when I want them (except W).
* I feel that you did a good job of giving me high points other than my ult.
* I was also wrong about my ADC using my Q buff. They recognized what it was and used it appropriately.

replies.body:
So basically he came in and said "No because I say so" to every point made and threw out straw man arguments that no one is stupid enough to believe. Go figure.

What was the point of this? The champion is less viable, less fun, clunky as hell and nothing positive was gained. The only thing that occurred is that it's ensured to never be played in the LCS/OGN and that those who enjoy the character are going to be forced to quit it or just lose a lot more often. There's been a 4% drop in Sona's win rate EVERY DAY at high Elo since these nerfs.

The win rate is not going up as time passes, it's going down. It's not a mechanically intensive champion (now just clunky), there are no changes in build style, nothing new really as far as her skills go to adapt to, nothing to adjust to at all. There is no adjustment period, this is it, she's far less viable than the old Sona and far less enjoyable.

Good job guy who ignores everyone's opinions, you've ruined yet another unique champion and won't even admit your screw-up. Oh and I almost forgot, stop nerfing Sona's breasts as well. As if nerfing her kit to death wasn't enough.

As hostile as I am to these changes I will also agree that I think your thought process behind this rework was good. Turning the auras into zones was a good idea but then you should have buffed Sona's armor and health if you want her to be in the front line especially since Sona is forced to build CDR/AP now instead of tanky if you want these auras to be impactful.  T**he reason her base stats are so low was because one upon a time her W used to give 20 armor and 20 mres and then the heal added another 20/20** even more, additionally **Aegis and Runic bulwark **added even more and she always took those. So now that the game has changed so much since then, including Sona herself and those items, why are Sona's base armor and health so low? Why did you further reduce her base health while at the same time slightly buffing her base armor? I am completely baffled and confused. There is a lack of consistency here.

 If you don't want her to be in the front line then you should have the radius of her zones scale larger into late game.

We did also increase the health per level for these reasons. That plus the base armor buff were to account for her no longer giving herself stats, but the fact that she has such frequent access to a shield limits how much base stats she needs to balance out the stat based squish factor.

She has 'such frequent access' to a 40+.2ap shield on a 10 sec cooldown that eats up her mana. You also decided to make her squishier from levels 1-3. That's the most baffling part of this for me. Again, you don't balance to the meta, but this meta is defined by level 2 all ins in bot lane. She's now even WORSE at those, and she was never great at them anyway. Why should I pick her in blind pick or teambuilder when a Leona or Braum on the other team makes my job incredibly difficult in bot lane?

I'm still at a loss to understand what was so oppressive about her 1-3 play that required explicit nerfs. I mean, just look at the passive on the ult. That just screams, "We're worried about her early-game power."

Originally, she was nerfed because she used to be incredibly domating as a support due to her poke and sustain meaning that she basically always had such a health advantage over you that you could barely farm. I severely doubt that's what would currently happen in this environment, given how squishy she is, but Riot is wary of going back to old style 'Q plus powerchord equals half your health'.
Yeah, but wasn't she originally developed as an anti/counterpoke champion where the counter-play was to go all-in? It feels like the meta response not only exists, but is incredibly robust.

Nowadays, it is, which is why I said that their fear that Sona would become overly dominating is probably unfounded, especially with those base stats. Back then, engage was much harder to do so, since Leona/Thresh/Braum didn't exist yet.

> I'm still at a loss to understand what was so oppressive about her 1-3 play that required explicit nerfs. I mean, just look at the passive on the ult. That just screams, "We're worried about her early-game power."

I think they do that to not make the 5 man invade level 1 to powerfull
Very possibly. However, would teamcomps built to exploit Sona's level 1 power be too toxic? I think it could be a fun thing to see, and completely counterable.

Too toxic or not remains to be seen, since it's still a completely viable invasion strategy.  Rank 1 of Hymn of Valor is the only rank that outdamages the old version, which may make Sona incredibly powerful for start-of-game invades and level 1 team-fights.  In complete comparison, Hymn loses power with each additional rank taken in it, which seems counter-intuitive to the fact that it has the shortest CD of her abilities and the rest of her kit is focused on late-game power.

Any chance you'd consider making the shield last just a little longer, lux's team wide shield lasts potentially up 6 seconds, sona's 1.5 second shield felt too short when I played her considering the positional requirements of it, say it give 2-2.5 seconds duration?

A lot of people suggest this. There is one strong argument against it, however. At 40% CDR, which is practically a requirement now, that leaves only six seconds between shields. If you lengthen the duration, you run the risk of her basically having 70-80% shield uptime. If she gets ahead, this would be really oppressive. It's already possible to get three shields off on your team in a fight.
Lux has a higher uptime on her shield at 40% CDR by a wide margin and no one calls it oppressive.
It also doesn't do anything but shield and is more complicated to apply. For all that tagging people with "snuggle zones" can feel like a pain, watching people dodge the wand hurts my soul.

>I have played two Co-Op vs. AI matches with her on live. While that may not sound like much, it's enough to get a feel for the reality of the rework.
> 

I'm going to have to disagree there. We don't build or balance the game for PvE, and I know I personally would never trust a sample size of 2 games to make meaningful analysis. 


> ______________________________________________________________________________
> 
> **A Rework Needs to Address a Champion's Place in the Game**
> 
 
> While this rework made her kit less toxic, it did nothing to address her position in the meta. 

So these two things are actually slightly at odds with themselves. When we evaluate a champion and make changes, we do spend a great deal of time making sure they have a place in the game as a whole. We constantly evaluate their strengths and weaknesses, their interactions with champs, items, etc. However, we don't (and I'd argue really shouldn't) try to make a champ fit the current meta. Meta, by definition will always favor some champs over others. Making Sona viable for the current meta is very likely to damage her position in the game. Basically, if the meta favors most of the champs that do well against Sona, and we make Sona strong in that environment, she has to be completely brokenly OP. If the meta capitalizes on Sona's weaknesses, and we make her strong despite that we end up having to give her no meaningful weakness.  

Going to reply in blocks due to the length of this. Our comment system is kind of exploding as I try this. Apologies for a slow response.

>Risk vs. Reward: Sona now has to be significantly closer to the front line, but she does not gain any benefit from this increased risk, nor were any of her stats changed to reflect this increased risk. She went from being a champion who sat at mid to long range, dipping in to poke, to a champion that has to "snuggle" down in the scrum to be effective. If you look over the complaints following the live release, this is among the most common.

This is not true. She was given increased base armor and increased HP for every level outside of 1-3. This means that she is more tanky for every common teamfight situation outside of level 1 fights. In level one fights, the power given from either a team wide Q proc or a full team shield is flat out bonkers. 

>It's worth noting that the enemy bruisers and assassins are going to be itching to have a squishy target to jump on. I saw this several times in my matches. I went forward to shield someone and was killed in an eye blink. That felt incredibly punishing.

I've seen the mindset in live games and in our playtests, but I've also seen Sona deal very well with the situation. An assassin that tries to brute force a kill on Sona will easily pay for it due to W PC, exhaust, ult and the increased shield + heal when used well. I'm not saying she might not die, but I think Sona has the tools to make sure her team comes out on top for it. 

>Another component of this ratio is that I am now forced to stack up with my allies, making me (and my allies) more vulnerable to AoE comps. The reward for tagging should at least be equal to the increased damage I take while stacked, but I don't feel that it is.

Haven't seen this playing out in ways that seem problematic. The ability to grant the entire team a shield, help them reposition, and give them a massive buff for the fight that happens in that grouping seems to balance this out to some degree. 

>There were several times in my matches where I couldn't get to my allies and this felt awful. This was especially bad in the early laning phase.

What stopped you from moving near your allies in early laning? Bots are especially not great at zoning, so very interested if there is a problem I'm not understanding. 

>Changing the risk vs. reward ratio is also very dangerous because it causes a massive change in feel. I already own risky supports. People who liked Sona now have to adapt to a much riskier position or give up on the champion. Given that she is mostly a fan pick as it is, this is really bad.

The idea of her being a less played champion isn't supported by global data. There are regions where she is very high in play rate. That being said, there is an adjustment cost for any update, and for Sona, one of the new elements is being in a place where you interact with your team more visibly and directly. That does increase risk, but mostly because old Sona had little incentive to work among her team outside of landing her ult. 

>This rework represents a massive increase in the amount of effort required to use her abilities "properly." I say this because it feels as though she was balanced around getting most, if not all, of her allies in her "snuggle zones." When I play her, I do not feel like I am rewarded for tagging people; I feel like this is the baseline and I am being punished when I can't get to my teammates. This is especially bad because Sona is touted as an easy, "entry-level" support.
>

Interested to see where you get that feeling. Break even point on Q for example is Sona using her proc. Any ally also using her proc is improved. Similar for W shield in terms of mitigation, though there is a higher awareness requirement.

Rather than continuously saying "You're wrong because this this this", can you at least acknowledge that yes, there is a problem with Sona's new implementation? HORDES of people are commenting that it feels clunky, and while there are lots of factually incorrect statements from players (especially re: math and so forth), it doesn't change the fact that there are **significant problems with gamefeel and satisfaction** that need to be addressed before she's in a good situation.

The biggest spot for this, in my opinion, is Sona's Q. It's the "use this to improve your team's offense" ability. Why is it that the only allies who benefit are autoattackers? And why does it only impact one attack when your team's main autoattackers - the ADC - do the vast majority of their damage from CONSISTENTLY autoattacking?

I understand that you've been busy, and you're in the midst of a crapload of damage control. I've seen your posts on the matter. I sympathize with you. But frankly, you are coming off as SUPER DEFENSIVE and not at all willing to accept that the players might have a different outlook than you.

These are things we are working on right now, and looking to figure out where we get the most bang for the buck. As for why we empower a single auto attack per Q per ally, this is about creating windows to actually fight back against Sona. If Sona could give her ADC 5 seconds of auto attacks empowered that the current level, or anything close to it, it would be very hard to trade at all for the entire duration. Making it one attack gives Sona's enemies a chance to react her actions, which creates more choices for Sona on how to optimize the use. Old Sona Q should be cast on cooldown if there are targets and Sona has mana. Making that choice deeper gives us room to make her more powerful.

I'm totally open to other outlooks. Mostly try to understand the outlooks right now, and figure out what improvements we can make in communication and satisfaction that don't impact balance before we have enough data to make any conclusions about her power level or success rate.
Make her Q also apply on ability damage as well? So if I'm, say...Maokai, and a Sona empowered me, my Sapling Toss will also inflict that bonus damage if I choose not to auto-attack?

I like this idea. It resonates with the old Q aura, and makes the buff remain useful even for pure skill users (no matter how minimal the damage increase is). As it is, the buff is completely useless for skill-based champions, and that's a shame.

The 'window to actually fight back against Sona' are 'levels 1-3, or, alternatively, whenever you can land a stun on her because she kinda explodes.' 

At the moment, she's a rather complicated support to play as, given how difficult optimizing the use of her Q actually is, given that the optimal use in a laning situation is 'when the enemy cannot attack back, when both lane opponents are in range, when you are close enough to your ADC that you can buff them, when your ADC has the presence of mind to know to use their next auto on an enemy champ, when the ADC is missing no CS by autoing that enemy champ, when you will have enough mana to W and possibly ult afterwards'.

Compare that to, say, Leona E. 'When the enemy is in range and not under tower, when your ADC has the presence of mind to follow up, when the ADC is in position to auto up, when you aren't obscenely behind, when you will have enough mana to Q and W afterwards.' Some of this is learned behavior, as ADCs have had years to learn that 'go in when the Leona does' but have had less than a week to learn 'after the Sona hits Q, your next auto will do more damage, so hit the enemy champ with it.' On the other hand, Leona's E-Q combo will do so much more than a single Sona Q if the enemy follows up, and Leona's not really in much danger if she doesn't dive under tower or something.

You're going to have to go full-Nami on her Q. In fact, after Nami, I'm not sure how Sona's Q went live. Nami players complained for weeks about how invisible the empowered attack was to her carry, and you radically improved the visual effect, sounds and everything. Then Sona comes out with mildly blue hands - I was playing with my premade and it wasn't until I mentioned it 15 minutes in that he realized I was even giving him an on-hit effect during his duels. 

It also needs to either only be trigger-able on champions and large minions/monsters, or you need to give the carry more than one (maybe 3?). Mainly because it seems to apply to in-progress attacks. I would use my Q to harass and then follow up with an auto, and by the second game with Sona my premade was attempting to also harass each time I Q'd - but half the time the on-hit effect would go on a minion that he was in the middle of attacking at the time.

It should only be triggered by full attack, not a projectile in flight. I'll look into that to make sure that's still working as intended.

As to having more attacks, the amount of damage you'd get if the proc was spread across many hits is going to feel really weak, even if the impact is powerful. We had a model of Q that empowered multiple attacks, and the satisfaction and understanding was really low.

We're still gathering feedback on the particles. If we have any changes on those, it would likely be a little down the road.

I had an idea in regards to giving teammates more empowered auto attacks: what if the empowered AAs could be shared?  To clarify, if Sona tagged herself and 2 other allies with the aura, then the tagged allies would be able to use a combined 3 empowered autos.  Aside from differing magic pen between teammates, this would allow the damage to be applied better without affecting the numbers too much, and it would help Sona since she could return to the center of her team sooner instead of having to chase to hit an AA to get the most out of the spell.

I've played two games on live. One in which I did pretty well cause I had my ad in skype. The other was a train wreck. IT LITERALLY TOOK TWO PEOPLE COORDINATING OVER VOICE CHAT TO MAKE IT WORK. Just trying to handle all that positioning/planning/map awareness on top of the normal support stuff was causing me to smoke from my ears. 

I don't enjoy new Sona, I'm fairly sure I could make her work but I would not have fun. This is pretty much the same thing they did with Karma. Ask questions, not reply for long time, come out with rework, tell everyone to try it before judging whilst we literally cant due to PBE, rush it out while ignoring feedback, act surprised when folks who enjoy said champs are upset.

All thats left is for Riot to say "Look at all the new people who enjoy Sona now! Fuck you old Sona players."

Yeah, I'm having trouble with the new system, as well. So I'm not going to be able to quote, as I can't figure out how to do that.

>I'm going to have to disagree there. We don't build or balance the game for PvE, and I know I personally would never trust a sample size of 2 games to make meaningful analysis. 

**EDIT: This is going to sound really testy, but it's an honest question. How many games in what formats do I need to play before I'm allowed to have and express an opinion that isn't immediately dismissed for lack of experience?**

I might not be able to speak to her overall viability, but I feel comfortable speaking about how I feel when I play her, where those feelings come from and what they mean. I don't have to eat 100 raw tomatoes to know that I can't eat them (they make me sick).  I haven't been able to get SR matches with her because my friends have been busy and I minimize my exposure to toxicity by queuing with them. I also wasn't going to go into a competitive environment without having at least experienced the mechanics. That's not fair to my team.

I just got done with an ARAM with her and I quizzed my teammates after the fact. I will say that I felt more comfortable with her. I still found the exercise of Q/AA or buff cumbersome. The shields felt more effective, but my allies didn't feel that they made that much difference. I was building utility because of the oppo comp, but I don't think that I should be forced to build CDR/AP to be effective.

The heal and shield combo still felt awkward.

When I asked how they felt about the Q buff, nither of them had noticed it. They said it wasn't visible enough for them to be aware of it and they both said that it was invisible power because the time frame was too short for them to change their action to take advantage of it.

>So these two things are actually slightly at odds with themselves. When we evaluate a champion and make changes, we do spend a great deal of time making sure they have a place in the game as a whole.

I think we're talking past each other a little bit here. I'm not asking you to address her relative position, though I am concerned about it. I want Sona to have a *role*. When I asked my friends, I put it this way:

If you were describing Sona to an inexperienced player, how would you finish this sentence: "You should bring Sona because _______________". 

If you can answer that question, I will gleefully concede the point.

> If you were describing Sona to an inexperienced player, how would you finish this sentence: "You should bring Sona because _______________". 
> 
> If you can answer that question, I will gleefully concede the point.

because: 

* Her ult is immensely powerful.
* She has great poke and sustain. 
* She gives her allies tremendous amounts of power in a team fight.

*Edit to fix formatting.*

I thought we were moving away from "Ult dispensing system" as a theme. I will grant you that it *is* an excellent reason to pick her and one of the things that drew me to her in the first place. Can we agree on strong partial credit?

I will agree that poke and sustain are qualities she has in significant measure, but I feel that they have been depreciated somewhat by the rework.

I don't really know how to respond to the third point, as that's basically why you bring *any* champion. I mean, no one's going to pick a champion that doesn't bring much to a team fight, right? I would feel more comfortable if you had a better description/vision for what *kind* of power she brings to a team fight.

However, I'm going to let this one go, because "powerful ult" isn't the answer I was hoping for, but it is an answer.

On the third point, the amount of power she gives to her allies compared to other supports and other champs in the game is a defining portion of Sona's kit. 

As much as we are giving Sona more impact outside of her ult, without changing Crescendo, it will always be so powerful that it will define a reason to take Sona. Sona's ult is really awesome, even if it's probably a little too amazing for the game sometimes.
Can you speak to how Crescendo is valued relative to similar ults on Wukong, Zyra and Amumu?
You can't compare abilities outside of their respective character kits. The three you pointed out have different weaknesses and strengths compared to Sona.

His comment boils down to "Sona can't have nice things because her ult is too good." My question is about how other large, disruptive ults limit or change the kit that they're on.

Flash + Ult is a common concern for Sona. Are there things that cannot be on Wukong because he can dash + ult? What does he give up for having that ult?

Zyra has significantly more burst, zone control and CC than Sona. People can walk out of her ult, but how does having a large knockup limit the rest of her kit?

Amumu's ult is much larger, but it's point blank and shorter. In terms of coordination and application, however, it's considerably easier to use.

I'd like to hear your response to the feeling that her poke and sustain have gone down with the rework. A lot of us really like Sona for being the attrition support, and it does seem like that got weaker with the rework. Do you agree?

> > If you were describing Sona to an inexperienced player, how would you finish this sentence: "You should bring Sona because _______________". 
> > 
> > If you can answer that question, I will gleefully concede the point.
> 
> because:
